decoDesc.decoNote: With an engraved title-page portrait of the author signed: "Martin- Droeshout: sculpsit¬∑ London.". The plate exists in 2 states: 1. The earlier state has lighter shading generall ; 2. Later state has heavier shading, especially around the collar, and minor differences particularly with the jawline and moustache. The vast majority of surviving copies have the plate in the second state which has led some scholars to conclude that the earlier state was a proof. The portrait in this copy is the second state.

bindingDesc.p: Seventeenth-century (1624) English (Oxford) smooth calf. Bound for the Bodleian Library by William Wildgoose, with evidence of two cloth ties, red sprinkled edge. Formerly chained, with evidence of chain staple at the head of the upper cover. Remains of paper label at the head of the spine. Enclosed in 20th century book box by Maltby of Oxford. See S. Gibson in Original Bodleian Copy of First Folio, p. 12-13. One of four items sent out on 17th February 1624 for binding by Wildgoose containing printed waste from a copy of Cicero‚Äôs "De Officiis, et al." [Deventer: Richard Pafraet, between 1480 and 1485] as paste-downs. For more information on this work see: Bod. Inc. Cat., C-322.

origin.p: For further details on the printing of this item see Hinman, Charleton. The printing and proof-reading of the First Folio of Shakespeare: Oxford, 1963.

acquisition.p: Acquired by the Bodleian in 1623, presumably in sheets. It was sent out to William Wildgoose on 17 February 1624 for binding (see: Library Records e.258, fol. 48r) and upon its return chained in Duke Humfrey at shelfmark S 2.17 Art. It is listed in the Bodleian‚Äôs 1635 catalogue of printed books but was gone by the publication of the next catalogue in 1674, replaced by the newer Third Folio (1664). There is no explicit reference in Library Records to the disposal of this copy, but there is a record of a sale of "superfluous library books" to Richard Davis, a bookseller in Oxford, in 1664 for the sum of ¬£24.

After leaving the Bodleian this copy entered the collection of Richard Turbutt of Ogston Hall, Derbyshire at some point in the early 18th century. It stayed in the family‚Äôs possession until 1906, when it was reacquired by the Bodleian for the sum of ¬£3000, raised by public subscription. For a full discussion of the rediscovery and purchase of this copy see: F. Madan, G. M. R. Turbutt and S. Gibson, The Original Bodleian Copy of the First Folio of Shakespeare (theTurbutt Shakespeare) (Oxford, 1905)
For a full discussion of this copy and the digital version see http://shakespeare.bodleian.ox.ac.uk/ and West and Rasmussen (2011), 31.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l:
Of Gouernment, the properties to vn¬≠
(fold,
Would seeme in me t'affect speech & discourse,
Since I am put to know, that your owne Science
Exceedes (in that) the lists of all aduice
My strength can giue you: Then no more remaines
But that, to your sufficiency, as your worth is able,
And let them worke: The nature of our People,
Our Cities Institutions, and the Termes
For Common Iustice, y'are as pregnant in
As Art, and practise, hath inriched any
That we remember: There is our Commission,
From which, we would not haue you warpe; call hither,
I say, bid come before vs Angelo:
What figure of vs thinke you, he will beare.
For you must know, we haue with speciall soule
Elected him our absence to supply;
Lent him our terror, drest him with our loue,
And giuen his Deputation all the Organs
Of our owne powre: What thinke you of it?

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.l: If any in Vienna be of worth
To vndergoe such ample grace, and honour,
It is Lord Angelo.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Looke where he comes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Alwayes obedient to your Graces will,
I come to know your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Angelo:
There is a kinde of Character in thy life,
That to th'obseruer, doth thy history
Fully vnfold: Thy selfe, and thy belongings
Are not thine owne so proper, as to waste
Thy selfe vpon thy vertues; they on thee:
Heauen doth with vs, as we, with Torches doe,
Not light them for themselues: For if our vertues
Did not goe forth of vs, 'twere all alike
As if we had them not: Spirits are not finely touch'd,
But to fine issues: nor nature neuer lends
The smallest scruple of her excellence,
But like a thrifty goddesse, she determines
Her selfe the glory of a creditour,
Both thanks, and vse; but I do bend my speech
To one that can my part in him aduertise;
Hold therefore Angelo:
In our remoue, be thou at full, our selfe:
Mortallitie and Mercie in Vienna
Liue in thy tongue, and heart: Old Escalus
Though first in question, is thy secondary.
Take thy Commission.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Now good my Lord
Let there be some more test, made of my mettle,
Before so noble, and so great a figure
Be stamp't vpon it.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: No more euasion:
We haue with a leauen'd, and prepared choice
Proceeded to you; therefore take your honors:
Our haste from hence is of so quicke condition,
That it prefers it selfe, and leaues vnquestion'd
Matters of needfull value: We shall write to you
As time, and our concernings shall importune,
How it goes with vs, and doe looke to know
What doth befall you here. So fare you well:
To th' hopefull execution doe I leaue you,
Of your Commissions.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yet giue leaue (my Lord,)
That we may bring you something on the way.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: My haste may not admit it,
Nor neede you (on mine honor) haue to doe
With any scruple: your scope is as mine owne,
So to inforce, or qualifie the Lawes
As to your soule seemes good: Giue me your hand,
Ile priuily away: I loue the people,
But doe not like to stage me to their eyes:
Though it doe well, I doe not rellish well
Their lowd applause, and Aues vehement:
Nor doe I thinke the man of safe discretion
That do's affect it. Once more fare you well.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: The heauens giue safety to your purposes.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.l:
Lead forth, and bring you backe in happi¬≠
nesse.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I thanke you, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.l: I shall desire you, Sir, to giue me leaue
To haue free speech with you; and it concernes me
To looke into the bottome of my place:
A powre I haue, but of what strength and nature,
I am not yet instructed.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Tis so with me: Let vs with‚Äêdraw together,
And we may soone our satisfaction haue
Touching that point.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.l: Ile wait vpon your honor.

div.head: Scena Secunda.
[Act 1, Scene 2]
div.stage: Enter Lucio, and two other Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
If the Duke, with the other Dukes, come not to
composition with the King of Hungary, why then all the
Dukes fall vpon the King.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p:
Heauen grant vs its peace, but not the King
of Hungaries.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Amen.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Thou eonclude'st like the Sanctimonious Pirat,
that went to sea with the ten Commandements, but
scrap'd one out of the Table.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Thou shalt not Steale?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I, that he raz'd.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p:
Why? 'twas a commandement, to command
the Captaine and all the rest from their functions: they
put forth to steale: There's not a Souldier of vs all, that
in the thanks‚Äëgiuing before meate, do rallish the petition
well, that praies for peace.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: I neuer heard any Souldier dislike it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I beleeue thee: for I thinke thou neuer was't
where Grace was said.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: No? a dozen times at least.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: What? In meeter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In any proportion. or in any language.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: I thinke, or in any Religion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I, why not? Grace, is Grace, despight of all con¬≠
trouersie: as for example; Thou thy selfe art a wicked
villaine, despight of all Grace.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Well: there went but a paire of sheeres be¬≠tweene vs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I grant: as there may between the Lists, and
the Veluet. Thou art the List.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p:
And thou the Veluet; thou art good veluet;
thou'rt a three pild‚Äêpeece I warrant thee: I had as liefe
be a Lyst of an English Kersey, as be pil'd, as thou art
pil'd, for a French Veluet. Do I speake feelingly now?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I thinke thou do'st: and indeed with most pain¬≠
full feeling of thy speech: I will, out of thine owne con¬≠
fession, learne to begin thy health; but, whilst I liue for¬≠
get to drinke after thee.

sp.speaker: 1. Gen.
sp.p: I think I haue done my selfe wrong, haue I not?

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p:
Yes, that thou hast; whether thou art tainted,
or free.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Behold, behold, where Madam Mitigation comes.
I haue purchas'd as many diseases vnder her Roofe,
As come to

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: To what, I pray?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Iudge

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.l: To three thousand Dollours a yeare.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.l: I, and more.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A French crowne more.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p:
Thou art alwayes figuring diseases in me; but
thou art full of error, I am sound.

sp.speaker: Luc.
1. Gent.
sp.p:
How now, which of your hips has the most
profound Ciatica?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Well, well: there's one yonder arrested, and
carried to prison, was worth fiue thousand of you all.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p: Who's that I pray'thee?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: Marry Sir, that's Claudio, Signior Claudio?

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: Claudio to prison? 'tis not so.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Nay, but I know 'tis so: I saw him arrested:
saw him carried away: and which is more, within these
three daies his head to be chop'd off.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
But, after all this fooling, I would not haue it so:
Art thou sure of this?

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
I am too sure of it: and it is for getting Madam
Iulietta with childe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Beleeue me this may be: he promis'd to meete
me two howres since, and he was euer precise in promise
keeping.

sp.speaker: 2. Gent.
sp.p:
Besides you know, it drawes somthing neere
to the speech we had to such a purpose.

sp.speaker: 1. Gent.
sp.p: But most of all agreeing with the proclamati≈ç proclamation .

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Away: let's goe learne the truth of it.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Thus, what with the war; what with the sweat,
what with the gallowes, and what with pouerty, I am
Custom‚Äëshrunke. How now? what's the newes
with you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yonder man is carried to prison.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: Well: what has he done?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A Woman.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: But what's his offence?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Groping for Trowts, in a peculiar Riuer.

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: What? is there a maid with child by him?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No: but there's a woman with maid by him:
you haue not heard of the proclamation, haue you?

sp.speaker: Baw.
sp.p: What proclamation, man?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
All howses in the Suburbs of Vienna must bee
pluck'd downe.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p: And what shall become of those in the Citie?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
They shall stand for seed: they had gon down
to, but that a wise Burger put in for them.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
But shall all our houses of resort in the Sub¬≠
urbs be puld downe?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p: To the ground, Mistris.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
Why heere's a change indeed in the Common¬≠
wealth: what shall become of me?

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Come: feare not you; good Counsellors lacke
no Clients: though you change your place, you neede
not change your Trade: Ile bee your Tapster still; cou¬≠
rage, there will bee pitty taken on you; you that haue
worne your eyes almost out in the seruice, you will bee
considered.

sp.speaker: Bawd.
sp.p:
What's to doe heere, Thomas Tapster? let's
withdraw?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Here comes Signior Claudio, led by the Prouost
to prison: and there's Madam Iuliet.

div.head: Scena Tertia.
[Act 1, Scene 2, cont.]
div.note: Conventionally this scene is not separate from the scene before.
div.stage: Enter Prouost, Claudio, Iuliet, Officers, Lucio, & 2.Gent.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Fellow, why do'st thou show me thus to th'world?
Beare me to prison, where I am committed.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I do it not in euill disposition,
But from Lord Angelo by speciall charge.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Thus can the demy‚Äëgod (Authority)
Make vs pay downe, for our offence, by waight
The words of heauen; on whom it will, it will,
On whom it will not (soe) yet still 'tis iust.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l:
Why how now Claudio? whence comes this res¬≠
(traint.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: From too much liberty, (my Lucio) Liberty
As surfet is the father of much fast,
So euery Scope by the immoderate vse
Turnes to restraint: Our Natures doe pursue
Like Rats that rauyn downe their proper Bane,
A thirsty euill, and when we drinke, we die.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
If I could speake so wisely vnder an arrest, I
would send for certaine of my Creditors: and yet, to say
the truth, I had as lief haue the foppery of freedome, as
the mortality of imprisonment: what's thy offence,
Claudio?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: What (but to speake of) would offend againe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: What, is't murder?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: No.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Lecherie?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Call it so.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Away, Sir, you must goe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: One word, good friend:
Lucio, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: A hundred:
If they'll doe you any good: Is Lechery so look'd after?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Thus stands it with me: vpon a true contract
I got possession of Iulietas bed,
You know the Lady, she is fast my wife,
Saue that we doe the denunciation lacke
Of outward Order. This we came not to,
Onely for propogation of a Dowre
Remaining in the Coffer of her friends,
From whom we thought it meet to hide our Loue
Till Time had made them for vs. But it chances
The stealth of our most mutuall entertainment
With Character too grosse, is writ on Iuliet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: With childe, perhaps?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Vnhappely, euen so.
And the new Deputie, now for the Duke,
Whether it be the fault and glimpse of newnes,
Or whether that the body publique, be
A horse whereon the Gouernor doth ride,
Who newly in the Seate, that it may know
He can command; lets it strait feele the spur:
Whether the Tirranny be in his place,
Or in his Eminence that fills it vp
I stagger in: But this new Gouernor
Awakes me all the inrolled penalties
Which haue (like vn‚Äëscowr'd Armor) hung by th'wall
So long, that ninteene Zodiacks haue gone round,
And none of them beene worne; and for a name
Now puts the drowsie and neglected Act
Freshly on me: 'tis surely for a name.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I warrant it is: And thy head stands so tickle on
thy shoulders, that a milke¬≠maid, if she be in loue, may
sigh it off: Send after the Duke, and appeale to him.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I haue done so, but hee's not to be found.
I pre'thee (Lucio) doe me this kinde seruice:
This day, my sister should the Cloyster enter,
And there receiue her approbation.
Acquaint her with the danger of my state,
Implore her, in my voice, that she make friends
To the strict deputie: bid her selfe assay him,
I haue great hope in that: for in her youth
There is a prone and speechlesse dialect,
Such as moue men: beside, she hath prosperous Art
When she will play with reason, and discourse,
And well she can perswade.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
I pray shee may; aswell for the encouragement
of the like, which else would stand vnder greeuous im¬≠
position: as for the enioying of thy life, who I would
be sorry should bee thus foolishly lost, at a game of ticke¬≠
tacke: Ile to her.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: I thanke you good friend Lucio.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Within two houres.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: Come Officer, away.

div.head: Scena Quarta.
[Act 1, Scene 3]

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: No: holy Father, throw away that thought,
Beleeue not that the dribling dart of Loue
Can pierce a compleat bosome: why, I desire thee
To giue me secret harbour, hath a purpose
More graue, and wrinkled, then the aimes, and ends
Of burning youth.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: May your Grace speake of it?

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: My holy Sir, none better knowes then you
How I haue euer lou'd the life remoued
And held in idle price, to haunt assemblies
Where youth, and cost, witlesse brauery keepes.
I haue deliuerd to Lord Angelo
(A man of stricture and firme abstinence)
My absolute power, and place here in Uienna
And he supposes me trauaild to Poland,
(For so I haue strewd it in the common eare)
And so it is receiu'd: Now (pious Sir)
You will demand of me, why I do this.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: Gladly, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: We haue strict Statutes, and most biting Laws,
(The needfull bits and curbes to headstrong weedes,)
Which for this foureteene yeares, we haue let slip,
Euen like an ore7#x2011;growne Lyon in a Caue
That goes not out to prey: Now, as fond Fathers,
Hauing bound vp the threatning twigs of birch,
Onely to sticke it in their childrens sight,
For terror, not to vse: in time the rod
More mock'd, then fear'd: so our Decrees,
Dead to infliction, to themselues are dead,
And libertie, plucks Iustice by the nose;
The Baby beates the Nurse, and quite athwart
Goes all decorum.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.l: It rested in your Grace
To vnloose this tyde‚Äëvp Iustice, when you pleas'd:
And it in you more dreadfull would haue seem'd
Then in Lord Angelo.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: I doe feare: too dreadfull:
Sith 'twas my fault, to giue the people scope,
'Twould be my tirrany to strike and gall them,
For what I bid them doe: For, we bid this be done
When euill deedes haue their permissiue passe,
And not the punishment: therefore indeede (my father)
I haue on Angelo impos'd the office,
Who may in th' ambush of my name, stri home,
And yet, my nature neuer in the fight
To do in slander: And to behold his sway
I will, as 'twere a brother of your Order,
Visit both Prince, and People: Therefore I pre'thee
Supply me with the habit, and instruct me
How I may formally in person beare
Like a true Frier: Moe reasons for this action
At our more leysure, shall I render you;
Onely, this one: Lord Angelo is precise,
Stands at a guard with Enuie: scarce confesses
That his blood flowes: or that his appetite
Is more to bread then stone: hence shall we see

div.l: If power change purpose: what our Seemers be.

div.head: Scena Quinta.
[Act 1, Scene 4]
div.stage: Enter Isabell and Francisca a Nun.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: And haue you Nuns no farther priuiledges?

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: Are not these large enough?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Yes truely; I speake not as desiring more,
But rather wishing a more strict restraint
Vpon the Sisterhood, the Votarists of Saint Clare.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Hoa? peace be in this place.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Who's that which cals?

sp.speaker: Nun.
sp.l: It is a mans voice: gentle Isabella
Turne you the key, and know his businesse of him;
You may; I may not: you are yet vnsworne:
When you haue vowd, you must not speake with men,
But in the presence of the Prioresse;
Then if you speake, you must not show your face;
Or if you show your face, you must not speake.
He cals againe: I pray you answere him.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Peace and prosperitie: who is't that cals?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Haile Virgin, (if you be) as those cheeke‚ÄëRoses
Proclaime you are no lesse: can you so steed me,
As bring me to the sight of Isabella,
A Nouice of this place, and the faire Sister
To her vnhappie brother Claudio?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Why her vnhappy Brother? Let me aske,
The rather for I now must make you know
I am that Isabella, and his Sister.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Gentle & faire: your Brother kindly greets you;
Not to be weary with you; he's in prison.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Woe me; for what?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: For that, which if my selfe might be his Iudge,
He should receiue his punishment, in thankes:
He hath got his friend with childe.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Sir, make me not your storie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: 'Tis true; I would not, though 'tis my familiar sin,
With Maids to seeme the Lapwing, and to iest
Tongue, far from heart: play with all Virgins so:
I hold you as a thing en‚Äëskied, and sainted,
By your renouncement, an imortall spirit
And to be talk'd with in sincerity,
As with a Saint.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: You doe blaspheme the good, in mocking me.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Doe not beleeue it: fewnes, and truth; tis thus,
Your brother, and his louer haue embrac'd;
As those that feed, grow full: as blossoming Time
That from the seednes, the bare fallow brings
To teeming foyson: euen so her plenteous wombe
Expresseth his full Tilth, and husbandry.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Some oe with childe by him? my cosen Iuliet?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Is she your cosen?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l:
Adoptedly, as schoole‚Äëmaids change their names
By vaine, though apt affection.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: She it is.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Oh, let him marry her.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: This is the point.
The Duke is very strangely gone from hence;
Bore many gentlemen (my selfe being one)
In hand, and hope of action: but we doe learne,
By those that know the very Nerues of State,
His giuing‚Äëout, were of an infinite distance
From his true meant designe: vpon his place,
(And with full line of his authority)
Gouernes Lord Angelo; A man, whose blood
Is very snow‚Äëbroth: one, who neuer feeles
The wanton stings, and motions of the sence;
But doth rebate, and blunt his naturall edge
With profits of the minde: Studie, and fast
He (to giue feare to vse, and libertie,
Which haue, for long, run‚Äëby the hideous law,
As Myce, by Lyons) hath pickt out an act,
Vnder whose heauy sence, your brothers life
Fals into forfeit: he arrests him on it,
And followes close the rigor of the Statute
To make him an example: all hope is gone,
Vnlesse you haue the grace, by your faire praier
To soften Angelo: And that's my pith of businesse
'Twixt you, and your poore brother.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Doth he so,
Seeke his life?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Has censur'd him already,
And as I heare, the Prouost hath a warrant
For's execution.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Alas: what poore
Abilitie's in me, to doe him good.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Assay the powre you haue.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My power? alas, I doubt.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Our doubts are traitors
And makes vs loose the good we oft might win,
By fearing to attempt: Goe to Lord Angelo
And let him learne to know, when Maidens sue
Men giue like gods: but when they weepe and kneele,
All their petitions, are as freely theirs
As they themselues would owe them.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Ile see what I can doe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: But speedily.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I will about it strait;
No longer staying, but to giue the Mother
Notice of my affaire: I humbly thanke you:
Commend me to my brother: soone at night
Ile send him certaine word of my successe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I take my leaue of you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Good sir, adieu.

div.head: Actus Secundus. Sc≈ìna Prima.
[Act 2, Scene 1]
div.stage: Enter Angelo, Escalus, and seruants, Iustice.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: We must not make a scar‚Äëcrow of the Law,
Setting it vp to feare the Birds of prey,
And let it keepe one shape, till custome make it
Their pearch, and not their terror.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.l: I, but yet
Let vs be keene, and rather cut a little
Then fall, and bruise to death: alas, this gentleman
Whom I would saue, had a most noble father,
Let but your honour know
(Whom I beleeue to be most strait in vertue)
That in the working of your owne affections,
Had time coheard with Place, or place with wishing,
Or that the resolute acting of our blood
Could haue attaind th' effect of your owne purpose,
Whether you had not sometime in your life
Er'd in this point, which now you censure him,
And puld the Law vpon you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: 'Tis one thing to be tempted (Escalus)
Another thing to fall: I not deny
The Iury passing on the Prisoners life
May in the sworne‚Äëtwelue haue a thiefe, or two
Guiltier then him they try; what's open made to Iustice,
That Iustice ceizes; What knowes the Lawes
That theeues do passe on theeues? 'Tis very pregnant,
The Iewell that we finde, we stoope, and take't,
Because we see it; but what we doe not see,
We tread vpon, and neuer thinke of it.
You may not so extenuate his offence,
For I haue had such faults; but rather tell me
When I, that censure him, do so offend,
Let mine owne Iudgement patterne out my death,
And nothing come in partiall. Sir, he must dye.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.l: Be it as your wisedome will.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Where is the Prouost?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Here if it like your honour.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: See that Claudio
Be executed by nine to morrow morning,
Bring him his Confessor, let him be prepar'd,
For that's the vtmost of his pilgrimage.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.l: Well: heauen forgiue him; and forgiue vs all:
Some rise by sinne, and some by vertue fall:
Some run from brakes of Ice, and answere none,
And some condemned for a fault alone.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Come, bring them away: if these be good peo¬≠
ple in a Common‚Äëweale, that doe nothing but vse their
abuses in common houses, I know no law: bring them away.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
How now Sir, what's your name? And what's
the matter?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
If it please your honour, I am the poore
Dukes Constable, and my name is Elbow; I doe leane vpon Ius¬≠
tice Sir, and doe bring in here before your good honor,
two notorious Benefactors.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Benefactors? Well: What Benefactors are they?
Are they not Malefactors?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
If it please your honour, I know not well what
they are: But precise villaines they are, that I am sure of,
and void of all prophanation in the world, that good
Christians ought to haue.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.l: This comes off well: here's a wise Officer.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
Goe to: What quality are they of? Elbow is
your name?
Why do'st thou not speake Elbow?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: He cannot Sir: he's out at Elbow.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
He Sir: a Tapster Sir: parcell Baud: one that
serues a bad woman: whose house Sir was (as they say)
pluckt downe in the Suborbs: and now shee professes a hotﬂõhouse; which, I thinke is a very ill house too.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: How know you that?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
My wife Sir? whom I detest before heauen, and
your honour.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: How? thy wife?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
I Sir: whom I thanke heauen is an honest wo¬≠
man.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: Do'st thou detest her therefore?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
I say sir, I will detest; my selfe also, as well as she,
that this house, if it be not a Bauds house, it is pitty of her life,
for it is a naughty house.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: How do'st thou know that, Constable?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Marry sir, by my wife, who, if she had bin a wo¬≠
man Cardinally giuen, might haue bin accus'd in forn¬≠
ication, adultery, and all vncleanlinesse there.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: By the womans meanes?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
I sir, by Mistris Ouerﬂõdons meanes: but as she spit
in his face, so she defide him.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Sir, if it please your honor, this is not so.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Proue it before these varlets here, thou honora¬≠ble
man, proue it.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: Doe you heare how he misplaces?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Sir, she came in great with childe: and longing
(sauing your honors reuerence) for stewd prewyns; sir,
we had but two in the house, which at that very distant
time stood, as it were in a fruit dish (a dish of some three
pence; your honours haue seene such dishes) they are not
China‚Äëdishes, but very good dishes.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: Go too: go too: no matter for the dish sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No indeede sir not of a pin; you are therein in
the right: but, to the point: As I say, this Mistris Elbow,
being (as I say) with childe, and being great bellied, and
longing (as I said) for prewyns: and hauing but two in
the dish (as I said) Master Froth here, this very man, ha¬≠
uing eaten the rest (as I said) & (as I say) paying for them
very honestly: for, as you know Master Froth, I could not
giue you three pence againe.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: No indeede.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Very well: you being then (if you be remem¬≠
bred) cracking the stones of the foresaid prewyns.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: I, so I did indeede.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why, very well: I telling you then (if you be
remembred) that such a one, and such a one, were past
cure of the thing you wot of, vnlesse they kept very good
diet, as I told you.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: All this is true.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Why very well then.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
Come: you are a tedious foole: to the purpose:
what was done to Elbowes wife, that hee hath cause to
complaine of? Come me to what was done to her.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Sir, your honor cannot come to that yet.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: No sir, nor I meane it not.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Sir, but you shall come to it, by your honours
leaue: And I beseech you, looke into Master Froth here
sir, a man of foure‚Äëscore pound a yeare; whose father
died at Hallowmas: Was't not at Hallowmas Master Froth?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: Allhallond‚ÄëEue.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why very well: I hope here be truthes: he Sir,
sitting (as I say) in a lower chaire, Sir, 'twas in the bunch
of Grapes, where indeede you haue a delight to sit, haue
you not?

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p: I haue so, because it is an open roome, and good for winter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Why very well then: I hope here be truthes.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
This will last out a night in Russia
When nights are longest there: Ile take my leaue,
And leaue you to the hearing of the cause;
Hoping youle finde good cause to whip them all.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
I thinke no lesse: good morrow to your Lord¬≠
ship. Now Sir, come on: What was done to Elbowes
wife, once more?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Once Sir? there was nothing done to her once.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
I beseech you Sir, aske him what this man did to
my wife.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I beseech your honor, aske me.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: Well sir, what did this Gentleman to her?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I beseech you sir, looke in this Gentlemans face:
good Master Froth looke vpon his honor; 'tis for a good
purpose: doth your honor marke his face?

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: I sir, very well.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Nay, I beseech you marke it well.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: Well, I doe so.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Doth your honor see any harme in his face?

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: Why no.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Ile be supposd vpon a booke, his face is the worst
thing about him: good then: if his face be the worst
thing about him, how could Master Froth doe the Con¬≠
stables wife any harme? I would know that of your
honour.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: He's in the right (Constable) what say you to it?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
First, and it like you, the house is a respected
house; next, this is a respected fellow; and his Mistris is
a respected woman.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
By this hand Sir, his wife is a more respected per¬≠
son then any of vs all.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Varlet, thou lyest; thou lyest wicked varlet: the
time is yet to come that shee was euer respected with
man, woman, or childe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Sir, she was respected with him, before he mar¬≠
ried with her.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
Which is the wiser here; Iustice or Iniquitie? Is
this true?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
O thou caytiffe: O thou varlet: O thou wick¬≠
ed
Hanniball; I respected with her, before I was married
to her? If euer I was respected with her, or she with me,
let not your worship thinke mee the poore Dukes Offi¬≠
cer: proue this, thou wicked Hanniball, or ile haue
mine action of battry on thee.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
If he tooke you a box o'th' eare, you might haue
your action of slander too.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Marry I thanke your good worship for it: what
is't your Worships pleasure I shall doe with this wick¬≠
ed Caitiffe?

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
Truly Officer, because he hath some offences in
him, that thou wouldst discouer, if thou couldst, let him
continue in his courses, till thou knowst what they are.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Marry I thanke your worship for it: Thou seest
thou wicked varlet now, what's come vpon thee. Thou
art to continue now thou Varlet, thou art to continue.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: Where were you borne, friend?

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p: Here in Vienna, Sir.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: Are you of fourescore pounds a yeere?

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.p: Yes, and't please you sir.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: So: what trade are you of, sir?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: A Tapster, a poore widdowes Tapster.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: Your Mistris name?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Mistris Ouer‚Äëdon.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: Hath she had any more then one husband?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Nine, sir: Ouerﬂõdon by the last.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
Nine? come hether to me, Master Froth; Master
Froth, I would not haue you acquainted with Tapsters;
they will draw you Master Froth, and you wil hang them:
get you gon, and let me heare no more of you.

sp.speaker: Fro.
sp.p:
I thanke your worship: for mine owne part, I
neuer come into any roome in a Tapﬂõhouse, but I am
drawne in.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
Well: no more of it Master Froth: farewell:
Come you hether to me, Mr. Tapster: what's your
name Mr. Tapster?

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: What else?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Bum, Sir.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
Troth, and your bum is the greatest thing about
you, so that in the beastliest sence, you are Pompey the
great; Pompey, you are partly a bawd, Pompey; howso¬≠
euer you colour it in being a Tapster, are you not? come,
tell me true, it shall be the better for you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Truly sir, I am a poore fellow that would liue.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
How would you liue Pompey? by being a bawd?
what doe you thinke of the trade Pompey? is it a lawfull
trade?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: If the Law would allow it, sir.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
But the Law will not allow it Pompey; nor it shall
not be allowed in Uienna.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Do's your Worship meane to geld and splay all
the youth of the City?

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: No, Pompey.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Truely Sir, in my poore opinion they will too't
then: if your worship will take order for the drabs and
the knaues, you need not to feare the bawds.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
There is pretty orders beginning I can tell you:
It is but heading, and hanging.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
If you head, and hang all that offend that way
but for ten yeare together; you'll be glad to giue out a
Commission for more heads: if this law hold in Vienna
ten yeare, ile rent the fairest house in it after three pence
a Bay: if you liue to see this come to passe, say Pompey
told you so.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
Thanke you good Pompey; and in requitall of
your prophesie, harke you: I aduise you let me not finde
you before me againe vpon any complaint whatsoeuer;
no, not for dwelling where you doe: if I doe Pompey, I
shall beat you to your Tent, and proue a shrewd C√¶sar
to you: in plaine dealing Pompey, I shall haue you whipt;
so for this time, Pompey, fare you well.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I thanke your Worship for your good counsell;
but I shall follow it as the flesh and fortune shall better
determine. Whip me? no, no, let Carman whip his Iade,
The valiant heart's not whipt out of his trade.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
Come hether to me, Master Elbow: come hither
Master Constable: how long haue you bin in this place
of Constable?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: Seuen yeere, and a halfe sir.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
I thought by the readinesse in the office, you had
continued in it some time: you say seauen yeares toge¬≠
ther.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: And a halfe sir.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
Alas, it hath beene great paines to you: they do
you wrong to put you so oft vpon't. Are there not men
in your Ward sufficient to serue it?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
'Faith sir, few of any wit in such matters: as they
are chosen, they are glad to choose me for them; I do it
for some peece of money, and goe through with all.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
Looke you bring mee in the names of some sixe
or seuen, the most sufficient of your parish.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: To your Worships house sir?

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p:
To my house: fare you well: what's a clocke,
thinke you?

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: Eleuen, Sir.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.p: I pray you home to dinner with me.

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.p: I humbly thanke you.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.l: It grieues me for the death of Claudio
But there's no remedie:

sp.speaker: Iust.
sp.l: Lord Angelo is seuere.

sp.speaker: Esc.
sp.l: It is but needfull.
Mercy is not it selfe, that oft lookes so,
Pardon is still the nurse of second woe:
But yet, poore Claudio; there is no remedie.
Come Sir.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Hee's hearing of a Cause; he will come straight,
I'le tell him of you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: 'Pray you doe; Ile know
His pleasure, may be he will relent; alas
He hath but as offended in a dreame,
All Sects, all Ages smack of this vice,and he
To die for't?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Now, what's the matter Prouost?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Is it your will Claudio shall die to morrow?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Did not I tell thee yea? hadst thou not order?
Why do'st thou aske againe?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Lest I might be too rash:
Vnder your good correction, I haue seene
When after execution, Iudgement hath
Repented ore his doome.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Goe to; let that be mine,
Doe you your office, or giue vp your Place,
And you shall well be spar'd.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I craue your Honours pardon:
What shall be done Sir, with the groaning Iuliet?
Shee's very neere her howre.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Dispose of her
To some more fitter place; and that with speed.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: Here is the sister of the man condemn'd,
Desires accesse to you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hath he a Sister?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I my good Lord, a very vertuous maid,
And to be shortlie of a Sister‚Äëhood,
If not alreadie.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well: let her be admitted,
See you the Fornicatresse be remou'd,
Let her haue needfull, but not lauish meanes,
There shall be order for't.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: 'Saue your Honour.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l:
Stay a little while: y'are welcome: what's your
(will?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I am a wofull Sutor to your Honour,
'Please but your Honor heare me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well: what's your suite.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: There is a vice that most I doe abhorre,
And most desire should meet the blow of Iustice;
For which I would not plead, but that I must,
For which I must not plead, but that I am
At warre, twixt will, and will not.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well: the matter?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I haue a brother is condemn'd to die,
I doe beseech you let it be his fault,
And not my brother.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Heauen giue thee mouing graces.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Condemne the fault, and not the actor of it,
Why euery fault's condemnd ere it be done:
Mine were the verie Cipher of a Function
To fine the faults, whose fine stands in record,
And let goe by the Actor:

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Oh iust, but seuere Law:
I had a brother then; heauen keepe your honour.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Giue't not ore so: to him againe, entreat him,
Kneele downe before him, hang vpon his gowne,
You are too cold: if you should need a pin,
You could not with more tame a tongue desire it:
To him, I say.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Must he needs die?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Maiden, no remedie.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Yes: I doe thinke that you might pardon him,
And neither heauen, nor man grieue at the mercy.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will not doe't.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: But can you if you would?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Looke what I will not, that I cannot doe.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: But might you doe't & do the world no wrong
If so your heart were touch'd with that remorse,
As mine is to him?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Hee's sentenc'd, tis too late.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You are too cold.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Too late? why no: I that doe speak a word
May call it againe: well, beleeue this
No ceremony that to great ones longs,
Not the Kings Crowne; nor the deputed sword,
The Marshalls Truncheon, nor the Iudges Robe
Become them with one halfe so good a grace
As mercie does: If he had bin as you, and you as he,
You would haue slipt like him, but he like you
Would not haue beene so sterne.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pray you be gone.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I would to heauen I had your potencie,
And you were Isabell: should it then be thus?
No: I would tell what 'twere to be a Iudge,
And what a prisoner.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I, touch him: there's the vaine.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Your Brother is a forfeit of the Law,
And you but waste your words.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Alas, alas:
Why all the soules that were, were forfeit once,
And he that might the vantage best haue tooke,
Found out the remedie: how would you be,
If he, which is the top of Iudgement, should
But iudge you, as you are? Oh, thinke on that,
And mercie then will breathe within your lips
Like man new made.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Be you content, (faire Maid)
It is the Law, not I, condemne your brother,
Were he my kinsman, brother, or my sonne,
It should be thus with him: he must die to morrow.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: To morrow? oh, that's sodaine,
Spare him, spare him:
Hee's not prepar'd for death; euen for our kitchins
We kill the fowle of season: shall we serue heauen
With lesse respect then we doe minister
To our grosse‚Äëselues? good, good my Lord, bethink you;
Who is it that hath di'd for this offence?
There's many haue committed it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: I, well said.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: The Law hath not bin dead, thogh it hath slept
Those many had not dar'd to doe that euill
If the first;, that did th'Edict infringe
Had answer'd for his deed. Now 'tis awake,
Takes note of what is done, and like a Prophet
Lookes in a glasse that shewes what future euils
Either now, or by remissenesse, new conceiu'd,
And so in progresse to be hatch'd, and borne,
Are now to haue no successiue degrees,
But here they liue to end.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Yet shew some pittie.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I shew it most of all, when I show Iustice;
For then I pittie those I doe not know,
Which a dismis'd offence, would after gaule
And doe him right, that answering one foule wrong
Liues not to act another. Be satisfied;
Your Brother dies to morrow; be content.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: So you must be yÕ§ the first that giues this sentence,
And hee, that suffers: Oh, it is excellent
To haue a Giants strength: but it is tyrannous
To vse it like a Giant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: That's well said.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Could great men thunder
As Ioue himselfe do's, Ioue would neuer be quiet,
For euery pelting petty Officer
Would vse his heauen for thunder;
Nothing but thunder: Mercifull heauen,
Thou rather with thy sharpe and sulpherous bolt
Splits the vn‚Äëwedgable and gnarled Oke,
Then the soft Mertill: But man, proud man,
Drest in a little briefe authoritie,
Most ignorant of what he's most assur'd,
(His glassie Essence) like an angry Ape
Plaies such phantastique tricks before high heauen,
As makes the Angels weepe: who with our spleenes,
Would all themselues laugh mortall.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Oh, to him, to him wench: he will relent,
Hee's comming: I perceiue't.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: Pray heauen she win him.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: We cannot weigh our brother with our selfe,
Great men may iest with Saints: tis wit in them,
But in the lesse fowle prophanation.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Thou'rt i'th right (Girle) more o'that.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: That in the Captaine's but a chollericke word,
Which in the Souldier is flat blasphemie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Art auis'd o'that? more on't.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Why doe you put these sayings vpon me?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Because Authoritie, though it erre like others,
Hath yet a kinde of medicine in it selfe
That skins the vice o'th top; goe to your bosome,
Knock there, and aske your heart what it doth know
That's like my brothers fault: if it confesse
A naturall guiltinesse, such as is his,
Let it not sound a thought vpon your tongue
Against my brothers life.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Shee speakes, and 'tis such sence
That my Sence breeds with it; fare you well.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Gentle my Lord, turne backe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I will bethinke me: come againe to morrow.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Hark, how Ile bribe you: good my Lord turn back.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: How? bribe me?

sp.speaker: Is.
sp.l: I, with such gifts that heauen shall share with you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: You had mar'd all else.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Not with fond Sickles of the tested‚Äëgold,
Or Stones, whose rate are either rich, or poore
As fancie values them: but with true prayers,
That shall be vp at heauen, and enter there
Ere Sunne rise: prayers from preserued soules,
From fasting Maides, whose mindes are dedicate
To nothing temporall.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Well: come to me to morrow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.l: Goe to: 'tis well; away.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Heauen keepe your honour safe.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Amen.
For I am that way going to temptation,
Where prayers crosse.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: At what hower to morrow,
Shall I attend your Lordship?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: At any time 'fore‚Äënoone.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: 'Saue your Honour.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: From thee: euen from thy vertue.
What's this? what's this? is this her fault, or mine?
The Tempter, or the Tempted, who sins most? ha?
Not she: nor doth she tempt: but it is I,
That, lying by the Violet in the Sunne,
Doe as the Carrion do's, not as the flowre,
Corrupt with vertuous season: Can it be,
That Modesty may more betray our Sence
Then womans lightnesse? hauing waste ground enough,
Shall we desire to raze the Sanctuary
And pitch our euils there? oh fie, fie, fie:
What dost thou? or what art thou Angelo?
Dost thou desire her fowly, for those things
That make her good? oh, let her brother liue:
Theeues for their robbery haue authority,
When Iudges steale themselues: what, doe I loue her,
That I desire to heare her speake againe?
And feast vpon her eyes? what is't I dreame on?
Oh cunning enemy, that to catch a Saint,
With Saints dost bait thy hooke: most dangerous
Is that temptation, that doth goad vs on
To sinne, in louing vertue: neuer could the Strumpet
With all her double vigor, Art, and Nature
Once stir my temper: but this vertuous Maid
Subdues me quite: Euer till now
When men were fond, I smild, and wondred how.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Haile to you, Prouost, so I thinke you are.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I am the Prouost: whats your will, good Frier?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Bound by my charity, and my blest order,
I come to visite the afflicted spirits
Here in the prison: doe me the common right
To let me see them: and to make me know
The nature of their crimes, that I may minister
To them accordingly.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: I would do more then that, if more were needfull
Looke here comes one: a Gentlewoman of mine,
Who falling in the flawes of her owne youth,
Hath blisterd her report: She is with childe,
And he that got it, sentenc'd: a yong man,
More fit to doe another such offence,
Then dye for this.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: When must he dye?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As I do thinke to morrow.
I haue prouided for you, stay a while
And you shall be conducted.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Repent you (faire one) of the sin you carry?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I doe; and beare the shame most patiently.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: Ile teach you how you shal araign your consciƒìce conscience
And try your penitence, if it be sound,
Or hollowly put on.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Ile gladly learne.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Loue you the man that wrong'd you?

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Yes, as I loue the woman that wrong'd him.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: So then it seemes your most offence full act
Was mutually committed.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Mutually.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Then was your sin of heauier kinde then his.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I doe confesse it, and repent it (Father.)

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: 'Tis meet so (daughter) but least you do repent
As that the sin hath brought you to this shame,
Which sorrow is alwaies toward our selues, not heauen,
Showing we would not spare heauen, as we loue it,
But as we stand in feare.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: I doe repent me, as it is an euill,
And take the shame with ioy.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: There rest:
Your partner (as I heare) must die to morrow,
And I am going with instruction to him:
Grace goe with you, Benedicite.

sp.speaker: Iul.
sp.l: Must die to morrow? oh iniurious Loue
That respits me a life, whose very comfort
Is still a dying horror.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: 'Tis pitty of him.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l: When I would pray, & think, I thinke, and pray
To seuerall subiects: heauen hath my empty words,
Whilst my Inuention, hearing not my Tongue,
Anchors on Isabell: heauen in my mouth,
As if I did but onely chew his name,
And in my heart the strong and swelling euill
Of my conception: the state whereon I studied
Is like a good thing, being often read
Growne feard, and tedious: yea, my Grauitie
Wherein (let no man heare me) I take pride,
Could I, with boote, change for an idle plume
Which the ayre beats for vaine: oh place, oh forme,
How often dost thou with thy case, thy habit
Wrench awe from fooles, and tye the wiser soules
To thy false seeming? Blood, thou art blood,
Let's write good Angell on the Deuills horne
'Tis not the Deuills Crest: how now? who's there?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.l: One Isabell, a Sister, desires accesse to you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Teach her the way: oh, heauens
Why doe's my bloud thus muster to my heart,
Making both it vnable for it selfe,
And dispossessing all my other parts
Of necessary fitnesse?
So play the foolish throngs with one that swounds,
Come all to help him, and so stop the ayre
By which hee should reuiue: and euen so
The generall subiect to a wel‚Äëwisht King
Quit their owne part, and in obsequious fondnesse
Crowd to his presence, where their vn‚Äëtaught loue
Must needs appear offence: how now faire Maid.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: I am come to know your pleasure.

sp.speaker: An.
sp.l:
That you might know it, wold much better please
(me,
Then to demand what 'tis: your Brother cannot liue.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Euen so: heauen keepe your Honor.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yet may he liue a while: and it may be
As long as you, or I: yet he must die.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Vnder your Sentence?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Yea.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: When, I beseech you: that in his Reprieue
(Longer, or shorter) he may be so fitted
That his soule sicken not.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Ha? fie, these filthy vices: It were as good
To pardon him, that hath from nature stolne
A man already made, as to remit
Their sawcie sweetnes, that do coyne heauens Image
In stamps that are forbid: 'tis all as easie,
Falsely to take away a life true made,
As to put mettle in restrained meanes
To make a false one.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: 'Tis set downe so in heauen, but not in earth.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Say you so: then I shall poze you quickly.
Which had you rather, that the most iust Law
Now tooke your brothers life, and to redeeme him
Giue vp your body to such sweet vncleannesse
As she that he hath staind?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Sir, beleeue this.
I had rather giue my body, then my soule.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I talke not of your soule: our compel'd sins
Stand more for number, then for accompt.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: How say you?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay Ile not warrant that: for I can speake
Against the thing I say: Answere to this,
I (now the voyce of the recorded Law)
Pronounce a sentence on your Brothers life,
Might there not be a charitie in sinne,
To saue this Brothers life?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Please you to doo't,
Ile take it as a perill to my soule,
It is no sinne at all, but charitie.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Pleas'd you to doo't, at perill of your soule
Were equall poize of sinne, and charitie.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: That I do beg his life, if it be sinne
Heauen let me beare it: you granting of my suit,
If that be sin, Ile make it my Morne‚Äëpraier,
To haue it added to the faults of mine,
And nothing of your answere.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay, but heare me,
Your sence pursues not mine: either you are ignorant,
Or seeme so crafty; and that's not good.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: Let be ignorant, and in nothing good,
But graciously to know I am no better.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Thus wisdome wishes to appeare most bright,
When it doth taxe it selfe: As these blacke Masques
Proclaime an en‚Äëshield beauty ten times louder
Then beauty could displaied: But marke me,
To be receiued plaine, Ile speake more grosse:
Your Brother is to dye.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: So.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: And his offence is so, as it appeares,
Accountant to the Law, vpon that paine.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: True.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Admit no other way to saue his life
(As I subscribe not that, nor any other,
But in the losse of question) that you, his Sister,
Finding your selfe desir'd of such a person,
Whose creadit with the Iudge, or owne great place,
Could fetch your Brother from the Manacles
Of the all‚Äëbuilding‚ÄëLaw: and that there were
No earthly meane to saue him, but that either
You must lay downe the treasures of your body,
To this supposed, or else to let him suffer:
What would you doe?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l: As much for my poore Brother, as my selfe;
That is: were I vnder the tearmes of death,
Th'impression of keene whips, I'ld weare as Rubies,
And strip my selfe to death, as to a bed,
That longing haue bin sicke for, ere I'ld yeeld
My body vp to shame.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Then must your brother die.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: And 'twer the cheaper way:
Better it were a brother dide at once,
Then that a sister, by redeeming him
Should die for euer.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Were not you then as cruell as the Sentence,
That you haue slander'd so?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Ignomie in ransome, and free pardon
Are of two houses: lawfull mercie,
Is nothing kin to fowle redemption.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: You seem'd of late to make the Law a tirant,
And rather prou'd the sliding of your brother
A merriment, then a vice.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Oh pardon me my Lord, it oft fals out
To haue, what we would haue,
We speake not what vve meane;
I something do excuse the thing I hate,
For his aduantage that I dearely loue.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: We are all fraile.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Else let my brother die,
If not a fedarie but onely he
Owe, and succeed thy weaknesse.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Nay, women are fraile too.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I, as the glasses where they view themselues,
Which are as easie broke as they make formes:
Women? Helpe heauen; men their creation marre
In profiting by them: Nay, call vs ten times fraile,
For we are soft, as our complexions are,
And credulous to false prints.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: I thinke it well:
And from this testimonie of your owne sex
(Since I suppose we are made to be no stronger
Then faults may shake our frames) let me be bold;
I do arrest your words. Be that you are,
That is a woman; if you be more, you'r none.
If you be one (as you are well exprest
By all externall warrants) shew it now,
By putting on the destin'd Liuerie.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I haue no tongue but one; gentle my Lord,
Let me entreate you speake the former language.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Plainlie conceiue I loue you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My brother did loue Iuliet,
And you tell me that he shall die for't.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: He shall not Isabell if you giue me loue.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I know your vertue hath a licence in't,
Which seemes a little fouler then it is,
To plucke on others.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Beleeue me on mine Honor,
My words expresse my purpose.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Ha? Little honor, to be much beleeu'd,
And most pernitious purpose: Seeming, seeming.
I will proclaime thee Angelo, looke for't.
Signe me a present pardon for my brother,
Or with an out‚Äëstretcht throate Ile tell the world aloud
What man thou art.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.l: Who will beleeue thee Isabell?
My vnsoild name, th' austeerenesse of my life,
My vouch against you, and my place i'th State,
Will so your accusation ouer‚Äëweigh,
That you shall stifle in your owne reporr,
And smell of calumnie. I haue begun,
And now I giue my sensuall race, the reine,
Fit thy consent to my sharpe appetite,
Lay by all nicetie, and prolixious blushes
That banish what they sue for: Redeeme thy brother,
By yeelding vp thy bodie to my will,
Or else he must not onelie die the death,
But thy vnkindnesse shall his death draw out
To lingring sufferance: Answer me to morrow,
Or by the affection that now guides me most,
Ile proue a Tirant to him. As for you,
Say what you can; my false, ore‚Äëweighs your true.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: To whom should I complaine? Did I tell this,
Who would beleeue me? O perilous mouthes
That beare in them, one and the selfesame tongue,
Either of condemnation, or approofe,
Bidding the Law make curtsie to their will,
Hooking both right and wrong to th' appetite,
To follow as it drawes. Ile to my brother,
Though he hath falne by prompture of the blood,
Yet hath he in him such a minde of Honor,
That had he twentie heads to tender downe
On twentie bloodie blockes, hee'ld yeeld them vp,
Before his sister should her bodie stoope
To such abhord pollution.
Then Isabell liue chaste, and brother die;
‚ÄúMore then our Brother, is our Chastitie.
Ile tell him yet of Angelo's request,
And fit his minde to death, for his soules rest.

sp.speaker: Du.
sp.l: So then you hope of pardon from Lord Angelo?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The miserable haue no other medicine

But onely hope: I'haue hope to liue, and am prepar'd to
die.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Be absolute for death: either death or life
Shall thereby be the sweeter. Reason thus with life:
If I do loose thee, I do loose a thing
That none but fooles would keepe: a breath thou art,
Seruile to all the skyie‚Äëinfluences
That dost this habitation where thou keepst
Hourely afflict: Meerely, thou art deaths foole,
For him thou labourst by thy flight to shun,
And yet runst toward him still. Thou art not noble,
For all th' accommodations that thou bearst,
Are nurst by basenesse: Thou'rt by no meanes valiant,
For thou dost feare the soft and tender forke
Of a poore worme: thy best of rest is sleepe,
And that thou oft prouoakst, yet grosselie fearst;
Thy death, which is no more. Thou art not thy selfe,
For thou exists on manie a thousand graines
That issue out of dust. Happie thou art not,
For what thou hast not, still thou striu'st to get,
And what thou hast forgetst. Thou art not certaine,
For thy complexion shifts to strange effects,
After the Moone: If thou art rich, thou'rt poore,
For like an Asse, whose backe with Ingots bowes;
Thou bearst thy heauie riches but a iournie,
And death vnloads thee; Friend hast thou none.
For thine owne bowels which do call thee, fire
The meere effusion of thy proper loines
Do curse the Gowt, Sapego, and the Rheume
For ending thee no sooner. Thou hast nor youth, nor age
But as it were an after‚Äëdinners sleepe
Dreaming on both, for all thy blessed youth
Becomes as aged, and doth begge the almes
Of palsied‚ÄëEld: and when thou art old, and rich
Thou hast; neither heate, affection, limbe, nor beautie
To make thy riches pleasant: what's yet in this
That beares the name of life? Yet in this life
Lie hid moe thousand deaths; yet death we feare
That makes these oddes, all euen.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I humblie thanke you.
To sue to liue, I finde I seeke to die,
And seeking death, finde life: Let it come on.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.l:
What hoa? Peace heere; Grace, and good com¬≠
panie.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l:
Who's there? Come in, the wish deserues a
welcome.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Deere sir, ere long Ile visit you againe.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Most holie Sir, I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: My businesse is a word or two with Claudio.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: And verie welcom: looke Signior, here's your sister.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Prouost, a word with you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.l: As manie as you please.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l:
Bring them to heare me speak, where I may be
conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Now sister, what's the comfort?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Why,
As all comforts are: most good, most good indeede,
Lord Angelo hauing affaires to heauen
Intends you for his swift Ambassador,
Where you shall be an euerlasting Leiger;
Therefore your best appointment make with speed,
To Morrow you set on.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Is there no remedie?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: None, but such remedie, as to saue a head
To cleaue a heart in twaine:

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: But is there anie?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Yes brother, you may liue;
There is a diuellish mercie in the Iudge,
If you'l implore it, that will free your life,
But fetter you till death.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Perpetuall durance?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: I iust, perpetuall durance, a restraint
Through all the worlds vastiditie you had
To a determin'd scope.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: But in what nature?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: In such a one, as you consenting too't,
Would barke your honor from that trunke you beare,
And leaue you naked.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Let me know the point.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Oh, I do feare thee Claudio, and I quake,
Least thou a feauorous life shouldst entertaine,
And six or seuen winters more respect
Then a perpetuall Honor. Dar'st thou die?
The sence of death is most in apprehension,
And the poore Beetle that we treade vpon
In corporall sufferance, finds a pang as great,
As when a Giant dies.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Why giue you me this shame?
Thinke you I can a resolution fetch
From flowrie tendernesse? If I must die,
I will encounter darknesse as a bride,
And hugge it in mine armes.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: There spake my brother: there my fathers graue
Did vtter forth a voice. Yes, thou must die:
Thou art too noble, to conserue a life
In base appliances. This outward sainted Deputie,
Whose setled visage, and deliberate word
Nips youth i'th head, and follies doth emmew
As Falcon doth the Fowle, is yet a diuell:
His filth within being cast, he would appeare
A pond, as deepe as hell.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: The prenzie, Angelo?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Oh 'tis the cunning Liuerie of hell,
The damnest bodie to inuest, and couer
In prenzie gardes; dost thou thinke Claudio,
If I would yeeld him my virginitie
Thou might'st be freed?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh heauens, it cannot be.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Yes, he would giu't thee; from this rank offence
So to offend him still. This night's the time
That I should do what I abhorre to name,
Or else thou diest to morrow.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Thou shalt not do't.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: O, were it but my life,
I'de throw it downe for your deliuerance
As frankely as a pin.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Thankes deere Isabell.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Be readie Claudio, for your death to morrow.

sp.speaker: Clau.
sp.l: Yes. Has he affections in him,
That thus can make him bite the Law by th'nose,
When he would force it? Sure it is no sinne,
Or of the deadly seuen it is the least.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Which is the least?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: If it were damnable, he being so wise,
Why would he for the momentarie tricke
Be perdurablie fin'de? Oh Isabell.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What saies my brother?

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Death is a fearefull thing.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: And shamed life, a hatefull.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: I, but to die, and go we know not where,
To lie in cold obstruction, and to rot,
This sensible warme motion, to become
A kneaded clod; And the delighted spirit
To bath in fierie floods, or to recide
In thrilling Region of thicke‚Äëribbed Ice,
To be imprison'd in the viewlesse windes
And blowne with restlesse violence round about
The pendant world: or to be worse then worst
Of those, that lawlesse and incertaine thought,
Imagine howling, 'tis too horrible.
The weariest, and most loathed worldly life
That Age, Ache, periury, and imprisonment
Can lay on nature, is a Paradise
To what we feare of death.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Alas, alas.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Sweet Sister, let me liue.
What sinne you do, to saue a brothers life,
Nature dispenses with the deede so farre,
That it becomes a vertue.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Oh you beast,
Oh faithlesse Coward, oh dishonest wretch,
Wilt thou be made a man, out of my vice?
Is't not a kinde of Incest, to take life
From thine owne sisters shame? What should I thinke,
Heauen shield my Mother plaid my Father faire:
For such a warped slip of wildernesse
Nere issu'd from his blood. Take my defiance,
Die, perish: Might but my bending downe
Repreeue thee from thy fate, it should proceede.
Ile pray a thousand praiers for thy death,
No word to saue thee.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Nay heare me Isabell.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: Oh fie, fie, fie:
Thy sinn's not accidentall, but a Trade;
Mercy to thee would proue it selfe a Bawd,
'Tis best that thou diest quickly.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.l: Oh heare me Isabella.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.l: Vouchsafe a word, yong sister, but one word.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.l: What is your Will.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p:
Might you dispense with your leysure, I would
by and by haue some speech with you: the satisfaction I
would require, is likewise your owne benefit.

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
I haue no superfluous leysure, my stay must be
stolen out of other affaires: but I will attend you a while.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Son, I haue ouer‚Äëheard what hath past between
you & your sister. Angelo had neuer the purpose to cor¬≠
rupt her; onely he hath made an assay of her vertue, to practise his iudgement with the disposition of natures.
She (hauing the truth of honour in her) hath made him
that gracious deniall, which he is most glad to receiue: I
am Confessor to Angelo, and I know this to be true, ther¬≠
fore prepare your selfe to death: do not satisfie your res¬≠
olution with hopes that are fallible, to morrow you
must die, goe to your knees, and make ready.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p:
Let me ask my sister pardon, I am so out of loue
with life, that I will sue to be rid of it.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Hold you there: farewell: Prouost, a word
with you.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: What's your will (father?)

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p:
That now you are come, you wil be gone: leaue
me a while with the Maid, my minde promises with my
habit, no losse shall touch her by my company.

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: In good time.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p:
The hand that hath made you faire, hath made
you good: the goodnes that is cheape in beauty, makes
beauty briefe in goodnes; but grace being the soule of
your complexion, shall keepe the body of it euer faire:
the assault that Angelo hath made to you, Fortune hath
conuaid to my vnderstanding; and but that frailty hath
examples for his falling, I should wonder at Angelo: how
will you doe to content this Substitute, and to saue your
Brother?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
I am now going to resolue him: I had rather
my brother die by the Law, then my sonne should be vn¬≠
lawfullie borne. But (oh) how much is the good Duke
deceiu'd in Angelo: if euer he returne, and I can speake
to him, I will open my lips in vaine, or discouer his go¬≠
uernment

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
That shall not be much amisse: yet, as the ma¬≠
tter now stands, he will auoid your accusation: he made
triall of you onelie. Therefore fasten your eare on my
aduisings, to the loue I haue in doing good; a remedie
presents it selfe. I doe make my selfe beleeue that you
may most vprighteously do a poor wronged Lady a me¬≠
rited benefit; redeem your brother from the angry Law;
doe no staine to your owne gracious person, and much
please the absent Duke, if peraduenture he shall euer re¬≠
turne to haue hearing of this businesse.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
Let me heare you speake farther; I haue spirit to
do any thing that appeares not fowle in the truth of my
spirit.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Vertue is bold, and goodnes neuer fearefull:
Haue you not heard speake of Mariana the sister of Fre¬≠
dericke the great Souldier, who miscarried at Sea?

sp.speaker: Isa.
sp.p:
I haue heard of the Lady, and good words went
with her name.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Shee should this Angelo haue married: was af¬≠
fianced to her oath, and the nuptiall appointed: between
which time of the contract, and limit of the solemnitie,
her brother Fredericke was wrackt at Sea, hauing in that
perished vessell, the dowry of his sister: but marke how
heauily this befell to the poore Gentlewoman, there she lost a noble and renowned brother, in his loue toward
her, euer most kinde and naturall: with him the portion
and sinew of her fortune, her marriage dowry: with
both, her combynate‚Äëhusband, this
well‚Äëseeming Angelo.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Can this be so? did Angelo so leaue her?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Left her in her teares, & dried not one of them with
his comfort: swallowed his vowes whole, prete¬≠
nding in her, discoueries of dishonor: in few, bestow'd
her on her owne lamentation, which she yet weares for
his sake: and he, a marble to her teares, is washed with
them, but relents not.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
What a merit were it in death to take this poore
maid from the world? what corruption in this life, that
it will let this man liue? But how out of this can shee a¬≠
uaile?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
It is a rupture that you may easily heale: and the
cure of it not onely saues your brother, but keepes you
from dishonor in doing it.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p: Shew me how (good Father.)

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p:
This fore‚Äënamed Maid hath yet in her the con¬≠
tinuance of her first affection: his vniust vnkindenesse
(that in all reason should haue quenched her loue) hath
(like an impediment in the Current) made it more vio¬≠
lent and vnruly: Goe you to Angelo, answere his req¬≠
uiring with a plausible obedience, agree with his demands
to the point: onely referre your selfe to this aduantage;
first, that your stay with him may not be long: that the
time may haue all shadow, and silence in it: and the place
answere to conuenience: this being granted in course,
and now followes all: wee shall aduise this wronged
maid to steed vp your appointment, goe in your place:
if the encounter acknowledge it selfe heereafter, it may
compell him to her recompence; and heere, by this is
your brother saued, your honor vntainted, the poore
Mariana aduantaged, and the corrupt Deputy scaled.
The Maid will I frame, and make fit for his attempt: if
you thinke well to carry this as you may, the doublenes
of the benefit defends the deceit from reproofe.
What thinke you of it?

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
The image of it giues me content already, and I
trust it will grow to a most prosperous perfection.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p:
It lies much in your holding vp: haste you spee¬≠
dily to Angelo, if for this night he intreat you to his bed,
giue him promise of satisfaction: I will presently to S. Lukes,
there at the moated‚ÄëGrange recides this deie¬≠
cted Mariana; at that place call vpon me, and
dispatch with Angelo, that it may be quickly.

sp.speaker: Isab.
sp.p:
I thank you for this comfort: fare you well good
father.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Nay, if there be no remedy for it, but that you
will needes buy and sell men and women like beasts, we
shall haue all the world drinke browne & white bastard.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: Oh heauens, what stuffe is heere.

sp.speaker: Clow.
sp.p:
Twas neuer merry world since of two vsuries
the merriest was put downe, and the worser allow'd by
order of Law; a fur'd gowne to keepe him warme; and
furd with Foxe and Lamb‚Äëskins too, to signifie, that craft
being richer then Innocency, stands for the facing.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Come your way sir: 'blesse you good Father
Frier.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p:
And you good Brother Father; what offence
hath this man made you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
Marry Sir, he hath offended the Law; and Sir,
we take him to be a Theefe too Sir: for wee haue found
vpon him Sir, a strange Pick‚Äëlock, which we haue sent
to the Deputie.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.l: Fie, sirrah, a Bawd, a wicked bawd,
The euill that thou causest to be done,
That is thy meanes to liue. Do thou but thinke
What 'tis to cram a maw, or cloath a backe
From such a filthie vice: say to thy selfe,
From their abhominable and beastly touches
I drinke, I eate away my selfe, and liue:
Canst thou beleeue thy liuing is a life,
So stinkingly depending? Go mend, go mend.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Indeed, it do's stinke in some sort, Sir:
But yet Sir I would proue.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Nay, if the diuell haue giuen thee proofs for sin
Thou wilt proue his. Take him to prison Officer:
Correction, and Instruction must both worke
Ere this rude beast will profit.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p:
He must before the Deputy Sir, he ha's giuen
him warning: the Deputy cannot abide a Whoreﬂõma¬≠
ster: if he be a Whore‚Äëmonger, and comes before him,
he were as good go a mile on his errand.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
That we were all, as some would seeme to bee
From our faults, as faults from seeming free.

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: His necke will come to your wast, a Cord sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I spy comfort, I cry baile: Here's a Gentleman,
and a friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
How now noble Pompey? What, at the wheels
of C√¶sar? Art thou led in triumph? What is there none
of Pigmalions Images newly made woman to bee had
now, for putting the hand in the pocket, and extracting
clutch'd? What reply? Ha? What saist thou to this
Tune, Matter, and Method? Is't not drown'd i'th last
raine? Ha? What saist thou Trot? Is the world as it was
Man? Which is the vvay? Is it sad, and few words?
Or how? The tricke of it?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Still thus, and thus: still vvorse?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
How doth my deere Morsell, thy Mistris? Pro¬≠
cures she still? Ha?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Troth sir, shee hath eaten vp all her beefe, and
she is her selfe in the tub.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Why 'tis good: It is the right of it: it must be
so. Euer your fresh Whore and your pouder'd Baud, an
vnshun'd consequence, it must be so. Art going to pri¬≠
son Pompey?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes faith sir.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Why 'tis not amisse Pompey: farewell: goe say
I sent thee thether: for debt Pompey? Or how?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: For being a baud, for being a baud.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Well, then imprison him: If imprisonment be
the due of a baud, why 'tis his right. Baud is he doubt¬≠
lesse, and of antiquity too: Baud borne. Farwell good
Pompey: Commend me to the prison Pompey, you vvill
turne good husband now Pompey, you will keepe the
house.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I hope Sir, your good Worship wil be my baile?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
No indeed wil I not Pompey, it is not the wear:
I will pray (Pompey) to encrease your bondage if you
take it not patiently: Why, your mettle is the more:
Adieu trustie Pompey.
Blesse you Friar.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: And you.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Do's Bridget paint still, Pompey? Ha?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: Come your waies sir, come.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: You will not baile me then Sir?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Then Pompey, nor now: what newes abroad Fr¬≠
ier? What newes?

sp.speaker: Elb.
sp.p: Come your waies sir, come.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Goe to kennell (Pompey) goe: What newes Frier of the Duke?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I know none: can you tell me of any?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Some say he is with the Emperor of Russia: other
some, he is in Rome: but where is he thinke you?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: I know not where: but wheresoeuer, I wish him well.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
It was a mad fantasticall tricke of him to steale
from the State, and vsurpe the beggerie hee was neuer
borne to: Lord Angelo Dukes it well in his absence:
he puts transgression too't.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: He do's well in't.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
A little more lenitie to Lecherie would doe no
harme in him: Something too crabbed that way, Frier.

sp.speaker: Duk.
sp.p: It is too general a vice, and seueritie must cure it.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Yes in good sooth, the vice is of a great kindred;
it is well allied, but it is impossible to extirpe it quite,
Frier, till eating and drinking be put downe. They say
this Angelo vvas not made by Man and Woman, after
this downe‚Äëright way of Creation: is it true, thinke
you?

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: How should he be made then?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Some report, a Sea‚Äëmaid spawn'd him. Some,
that he vvas begot betweene two Stock‚Äëfishes. But it
is certaine, that when he makes water, his Vrine is con¬≠
geal'd ice, that I know to bee true: and he is a motion
generatiue, that's infallible.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You are pleasant sir, and speake apace.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Why, what a ruthlesse thing is this in him, for
the rebellion of a Cod‚Äëpeece, to take away the life of a
man? Would the Duke that is absent haue done this? Ere
he would haue hang'd a man for the getting a hun¬≠
dred Bastards, he vvould haue paide for the Nursing
a thousand. He had some feeling of the sport, hee knew
the seruice, and that instructed him to mercie.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I neuer heard the absent Duke much detected
for Women, he was not enclin'd that vvay.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh Sir, you are deceiu'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: 'Tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Who, not the Duke? Yes, your beggar of fifty:
and his vse was, to put a ducket in her Clack‚Äëdish; the
Duke had Crochets in him. Hee would be drunke too,
that let me informe you.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: You do him wrong, surely.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Sir, I vvas an inward of his: a shie fellow vvas
the Duke, and I beleeue I know the cause of his vvith¬≠
drawing.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: What (I prethee) might be the cause?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
No, pardon: 'Tis a secret must bee lockt with¬≠
in the teeth and the lippes: but this I can let you vnder¬≠
stand, the greater file of the subiect held the Duke to be
vvise.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Wise? Why no question but he was.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: A very superficiall, ignorant, vnweighing fellow

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Either this is Enuie in you, Folly, or mista¬≠
king: The very streame of his life, and the businesse he
hath helmed, must vppon a warranted neede, giue him
a better proclamation. Let him be but testimonied in
his owne bringings forth, and hee shall appeare to the
enuious, a Scholler, a Statesman, and a Soldier: there¬≠
fore you speake vnskilfully: or, if your knowledge bee
more, it is much darkned in your malice.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, I know him, and I loue him.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Loue talkes with better knowledge, & know¬≠
ledge with deare loue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come Sir, I know what I know.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
I can hardly beleeue that, since you know not
what you speake. But if euer the Duke returne (as our
